toolkit.transformers package¶

Submodules¶

toolkit.transformers.classifiers module¶

Naive Bayes classifier.

class toolkit.transformers.classifiers.NBClassifier(label_probdist=None, feature_probdist=None, estimator=<class 'nltk.probability.ELEProbDist'>)[source]¶

Bases: sklearn.base.TransformerMixin

Naive Bayes classifier for part-of-text classification.

The classifier creates a wrapper around NLTK NaiveBayesClassifier and implements transform and fit_transform methods suitable for pipeline integration.

Parameters:
  • label_probdist –

    P(label)

    The probability distribution over labels.

    It is expressed as a ProbDistI whose samples are labels. I.e., P(label) = label_probdist.prob(label).

  • feature_probdist –

    P(fname=fval|label)

    The probability distribution for feature values, given labels.

    It is expressed as a dictionary whose keys are (label, fname) pairs and whose values are ProbDistI objects over feature values. I.e., P(fname=fval|label) = feature_probdist[label,fname].prob(fval). If a given (label,fname) is not a key in feature_probdist, then it is assumed that the corresponding P(fname=fval|label) is 0 for all values of fval.
evaluate(X: Iterable, y: Iterable, sample, n=3, filter_hooks=None)[source]¶

Perform evaluation of the classifier instance.

Parameters:
  • X –

    Iterable, test data

    Same shape as for fit and fit_predict methods

  • y – Iterable, of labels
  • sample –

    one of labels to get the prediction for

    For example, if labels are [‘class_A’, ‘class_B’, ‘class_C’], the sample could be ‘class_A’.

  • n – int, number of candidates to output
  • filter_hooks –

    list of hooks, will be used to filter predictions

    The hook should take a tuple of ((word, tag), score) as its parameter and output boolean whether or not it passes the filter.
export(export_dir=None, export_name=None) → str[source]¶

Export timestamped pickled classifier to the given directory.

Returns:path to the timestamped .checkpoint file
features¶

Return features most informative for classification.

fit(X: Iterable, y=None, **fit_params)[source]¶

Fits the classifier to the given data set.

Parameters:
  • X –

    Iterable, output of FeatureExtractor

    The X is expected to be an iterable of tuples (tagged_word, feature_set, label), where feature set is a dictionary of evaluated features. The format of X matches the output of FeatureExtractor.

  • y – redundant (included to preserve base class method definition)
fit_predict(X: Iterable, y=None, **fit_params)[source]¶

Make prediction about the given data.

Parameters:
  • X –

    Iterable, prediction data

    The prediction data is expected to be of type List[(name_tuple, feature_set [,feature,label)] where feature_set corresponds to the output of FeatureExtractor and feature labels (if provided) should be None (will be ignored anyway).

  • y – redundant (included to preserve bace class method definition)
  • fit_params –

    kwargs, fit parameters

    n: number of candidates to output sample: one of labels to get the prediction for (for example, if labels are [‘class_A’, ‘class_B’, ‘class_C’], the sample could be ‘class_A’. filter_hooks: list of hooks, will be used to filter predictions

    The hook should take a tuple of ((word, tag), score) as its parameter and output boolean whether or not it passes the filter.
predict(features: dict, sample=None) → Any[source]¶

Make predictions based on given features.

Parameters:
  • features –

    dict, features to be used for prediction

    Dictionary of (feature_key, feature_value)

  • sample – one of labels to get the prediction for (for example, if labels are [‘class_A’, ‘class_B’, ‘class_C’], the sample could be ‘class_A’.
Returns:

Union[float, dict]

If sample is specified, returns P(sample|features), ie the probability of sample given features, where sample is one of labels. Otherwise returns dict of (label: max_prob) for all known labels.
static restore(checkpoint) → toolkit.transformers.classifiers.NBClassifier[source]¶

Restores the classifier from a checkpoint file.

Parameters:checkpoint –

path to directory or specific checkpoint

If path to directory provided, the newest checkpoint is restored.
show_most_informative_features()[source]¶

transform(X)[source]¶

Auxiliary function to be used in pipeline.

toolkit.transformers.classifiers.cross_validate(classifier, X: Iterable, y: Iterable, sample, n=3, folds=10, filter_hooks=None, shuffle=True)[source]¶

Evaluate cross-validation accuracy of the classifier.

Note: this method DOES NOT evaluate the INSTANCE of the classifier. Instead, it trains a shadow classifier of the same parameters as the given classifier and evaluates its accuracy.

Parameters:
  • classifier – NBClassifier instance to be evaluated
  • X –

    Iterable of train data

    The same as is provided to fit method.

  • y – Iterable of labels
  • sample –

    one of labels

    one of labels to get the prediction for (for example, if labels are [‘class_A’, ‘class_B’, ‘class_C’], the sample could be ‘class_A’.

  • n – int, number of candidates to output
  • folds – int, number of folds to be used for cross-validation
  • filter_hooks –

    list of hooks, will be used to filter predictions

    The hook should take a tuple of ((word, tag), score) as its parameter and output boolean whether or not it passes the filter.

  • shuffle –

    whether to shuffle the data

    If None, no cross-validaiton is performed
toolkit.transformers.classifiers.precision(total: int, correct: int) → float[source]¶

Calculate precision.

toolkit.transformers.classifiers.weighted_precision(y_true, y_pred, weights)[source]¶

Calculate weighted precision.

toolkit.transformers.extractors module¶

This module contains transformers and feature extractors.

The transformers are used in train and predict pipelines and implement the transform or fit_transform methods for this purpose

class toolkit.transformers.extractors.FeatureExtractor(feature_hooks: Iterable = None, share_hooks=False)[source]¶

Bases: sklearn.base.TransformerMixin

Feature extractor implementing transform for scikit pipelines.

By default, constructs vanilla feature extractor with basic features and positional context information.

Parameters:feature_hooks –

Union[dict, list]

either dict of: {feature_key: function}, or list of <class Hook>

Specify features which should be extracted from the given set. The hooks are called for each element of the set and return corresponding features.
feature_keys¶

Return list of hooks of selected feature_keys.

fit(X, y=None, **fit_params)[source]¶

Fit the transformer to the given data.

Parameters:
  • X –

    Iterable, each element should be a list of tuples (token, tag)

    Ie. an input should be a list of tuples List[(token, tag)], which is expected to be the output of NLTKPreprocessor or custom tokenization process.

  • y – Iterable of len(X), target values
  • fit_params –

    kwargs, optional arguments to be used during fitting

    skip_unfed_hooks:
     bool, whether to skip unfed hooks
transform(X: Iterable) → list[source]¶

Apply transformation to each element in X.

Parameters:X –

Iterable, each element should be a list of tuples (token, tag)

Ie. an input should be a list of tuples List[(token, tag)], which is expected to be the output of NLTKPreprocessor or custom tokenization process.
Returns:list

This transformation outputs list of the shape (len(X),) where each element of the list is a nested list of tuples of type (tagged_word, dictionary{feature_key: value}, classification label). The classification label is a bool indicating whether the label provided by y to the fit matches the token.

The keys of those features (dictionaries), are names of the feature_keys, ie. hooks and the values are the values of those extracted feature_keys.

toolkit.transformers.feature_hooks module¶

Feature hooks for extractors.

toolkit.transformers.feature_hooks.has_uppercase_hook = <toolkit.transformers.hooks.Hook object>¶

Hook: Return whether the word in tagged contains uppercase letter.

toolkit.transformers.feature_hooks.is_alnum_hook = <toolkit.transformers.hooks.Hook object>¶

Hook: Return whether the word contains only alphanumeric characters.

toolkit.transformers.feature_hooks.vendor_product_match_hook = <toolkit.transformers.hooks.Hook object>¶

Hook: Return whether the given word matches vendor or product.

toolkit.transformers.feature_hooks.ver_follows_hook = <toolkit.transformers.hooks.Hook object>¶

Hook: Return whether the given word is followed by a version string.

toolkit.transformers.feature_hooks.ver_pos_hook = <toolkit.transformers.hooks.Hook object>¶

Hook: Return version position in the tagged w.r.t the given word.

toolkit.transformers.feature_hooks.word_len_hook = <toolkit.transformers.hooks.Hook object>¶

Hook: Compare length of word in tagged to the limit.

toolkit.transformers.hooks module¶

This module contains the Hook class to handle pipeline hooks.

class toolkit.transformers.hooks.Hook(key: str, func, reuse=False, **default_kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

Convenient class for handling hooks.

Parameters:
  • key – str, unique identifier of the hook
  • func –

    function to be called by the hook

    The function can not modify any items fed by its arguments.

  • default_kwargs –

    default func keyword argument values

    Example: def foo(x, verbose=False):

    if verbose:
    print(‘verbosity on’)

    return x

    # init with default kwargs foo_hook = Hook(‘foo’, foo, verbose=True) # and on the call foo_hook(x=None) # prints ‘verbosity on’

  • reuse – whether to reuse (share) the Hook
classmethod clear_current_instances()[source]¶

Clean up the references held by the class.

This function is not usually called by user, mainly used for tests where cleanup is needed.

default_kwargs¶

Get hook default keyword arguments.

classmethod get_current_hooks() → list[source]¶

Return instances of this class.

classmethod get_current_keys() → set[source]¶

Return keys to the instances of this class.

key¶

Get hook key.
